awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Community and Teacher Teams Investigate Equitable Noticing and Dispositions
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will examine how teachers can engage a broad range of learners in rigorous mathematical activity. A significant component of this work is designing and investigating a process of mathematics teachers' learning to attend to students' mathematical reasoning and participation in their learning. A particular focus of the work will be investigating how teachers' pay attention to student engagement in their classrooms from an equity perspective. The three goals of the project include exploring the relation between teachers' backgrounds, classroom noticing, and instruction; investigating a professional development model for teachers; and designing tools to support other mathematics teachers in learning to notice their students? strengths. The project will involve community leaders as participants in the professional development in order to relate student engagement in the mathematics classroom to students? communities and cultures. This project is supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field.

Teacher noticing is a central component of mathematics teaching. The study is situated in sociocultural theories of learning and development that connect patterns of noticing in the classroom to participation in social and cultural communities. The goal of the study is to extend this framework to noticing for equity in the mathematics classroom using a community-based design approach. The study includes three research questions. (1) What is the relation between the dispositions, noticing practices, and mathematics instruction of secondary mathematics teachers? (2) What activities, tools and frameworks support teachers in learning to notice for equity? (3) How can a community-based design model enhance the conceptualization of noticing for equity and the development of tools/frameworks for teacher learning? The project will include the design of a professional development for two cohorts of secondary teachers in collaboration with community leaders. The project will also develop tools for research that can be used in other projects that investigate teacher noticing for equity in mathematics. Data collected will include teacher interviews, video documentation of teacher and community leader interactions in professional development (including summer design charrettes), other documents and artifacts from the design of tools and resources, and other qualitative data. Multiple frameworks will be used for data analysis.

por.por_cntn:
Co-Attend CUB Project Outcomes


The Co-Attend project brought together mathematics teachers, leaders of community-based organizations and university scholars to learn to notice equitable outcomes and humanizing experiences for minoritized students in secondary mathematics education. The primary purpose of the research was to study the participatory model of diverse education stakeholders working collaboratively to solve intractable education problems like equity in mathematics. A second purpose was to understand more deeply how the lives of members of the project shaped both by personal experience as well as location in broader social, cultural, and political hierarchies mediated their participation and noticing. The project spanned two sites. This report focuses primarily on the activities and outcomes from the team at the University of Colorado Boulder. 


One objective of the project was to design and support a two-year participatory research collaboration. The collaboration brought together a cohort of four secondary teachers, three community leaders, one university postdoctoral scholar, two graduate students, and one university professor. The cohort (cohort 1) engaged in biweekly noticing meetings and two summer institutes. The first weeklong summer institute lay the groundwork for noticing meetings, in which the cohort engaged in embodied, multisensory noticing and discussed and grappled with ideas such as equity and justice. Following the institute, the group met on a biweekly basis around research articles and videos of the teachers’ classroom instruction to grapple with and begin to conceptualize noticing for equity. The second summer institute focused on honing these conceptualizations and jointly identifying other take-aways from the work. The cohort decided to pursue two sets of outcomes. One set of outcomes was jointly  pursued research studies on the collaboration, which are slated to be published in an edited book. A second outcome was a collaborative approach to the design of a professional development for secondary mathematics teachers on learning to notice for equity. The cohort also jointly developed a symposium proposal for AERA (which was later accepted), and one of the doctoral students completed a dissertation on noticing for translanguaging in mathematics.


COVID19 thwarted and/or postponed intended activites for 2019 - 2020, including the AERA symposium, the PD, and continued work on the chapters. Some of these were restarted in the 4th year of the project. 


In the third year of the project, a second doctoral student pursued participatory research on anti-racist noticing practices. What she eventually called the “Black Joy” team involved the doctoral student, the university professor, two community members from cohort 1, and two new teachers who identified as Black and with whom the PI had previously work. The Black Joy cohort met for two years and became the primary focus of the doctoral student’s disseration, which was completed in summer, 2022. 


The fourth year of the project (2021-2022) focused on the recruitment of a second cohort of secondary math teachers for the PD designed by the first cohort. The second cohort, five secondary mathematics teachers, participated in the PD on a biweekly basis over the course of the academic year. The teachers engaged in noticing interviews and in other activities designed by cohort 1, culminating in action research projects. Two papers led by the graduate students focused on outcomes of the 4th year and were accepted by the Psychology of Mathematics Education conference.  


Three of the cohort 2 teachers helped redesign and facilitate two PDs in the fifth year of the project (2022-2023). One PD was co-led by one teacher and one graduate student, while a second one was led by two teachers and a second graduate student. Both PDs were successful and engaged ten new teachers (cohort 3) in the redesigned PD. 


The final year of the project (2023-2024) was dedicated to finishing the final PDs and initial data analysis of the outcomes. Graduate students also co-wrote book chapters for the edited volume with the math teachers who co-led the PDs with them on the outcomes of this PD.


In summary, this project served to theorize teacher noticing for equity in ways that advanced the field’s understanding of teacher noticing as embodied and multisensory, and bound up in particular discourses that either reify or disrupt deficit ideologies. The professional development that was designed and refined over time illuminated the challenges mathematics teachers from dominant identities face in noticing for equity. Our research points to the  importance of deliberate and collective attention to the ways that historical processes and structures mediate classroom mathematics learning, and to the ways that teachers’ discourses are aligned with deficit perspectives of BIPOC youth, their families, and their communities. We have presented these findings at professional conferences, in dissertations, journal articles, invited talks, and in a edited book collaboratively written with teachers and community leaders that we plan to complete by the of the year.
